instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v/300ma or 20v/0ma with battery
threads.message:
Board came in with corrosion around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3000</CHIP> was corroded and missing a pad, some other pads on board needed to be rebuild and some resistors <RESISTOR>R3105</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3108</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3109</RESISTOR> also got replaced as well as both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3000</CHIP>, I still only get 5v and 300ma with board alone, whats weird is that the battery has a charge still and board powers on, when I plug in the charger on the affected port with the board on the casing I get 5v when I first plug in, but if I unplug it and plug it back on then I get nothing on the meter, all other ports while the board is on the casing give me 20v wit 0a.

<SIGNAL>PPB3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> is 3.3v

I was barely getting a hang of the older boards, this USB-C boards are kicking my ass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v/300ma or 20v/0ma with battery
threads.message:
Do you get 20V on 3 ports and only one stays at 5V/300mA?
300mA is too much for USB-C port stuck on 5V.
Compare diode readings on LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v/300ma or 20v/0ma with battery
threads.message:
Diode mode on all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is 0.500

To be exact with no battery I get 5.1v and 0.25a on all ports
With battery I get 20v 0a and 3 ports and port with corrosion gets 5.1v and 0.25a but only when I first plug in the charger, after that I connect it and meter shows a blank screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v/300ma or 20v/0ma with battery
threads.message: By the way, this board has CD3215C00Z and I replaced it with CD3215C00, not sure if that affects anything

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v/300ma or 20v/0ma with battery
threads.message:
You still have problems on the USB-C port with different behaviour.
And I doubt that you get 0.500 on ALL 4 LDO outputs of each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v/300ma or 20v/0ma with battery
threads.message:
I now got it, those LDO lines are pins 2,35,53 and 75 on the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> they all range from 0.480 to 0.515 on this board it turns out my "new" <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> were all BAD, I got this fixed using a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> from another board after rebuilding some lost traces.

Thanks again!
